title: Multifocal Motor Neuropathy (MMN)
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) in adults. Includes diagnostic criteria (EFNS/PNS), electrodiagnostic findings including motor conduction block, anti-GM1 antibody testing, and IVIg therapy. Covers differential diagnosis with ALS (critical mimic), CIDP, and other motor neuron/neuropathy disorders. Excludes Lewis-Sumner syndrome (multifocal acquired demyelinating sensory and motor neuropathy — MADSAM) as separate entity but includes in differential.

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Renal/hepatic function baseline before IVIg; electrolytes
Present in ~50% of MMN; supports diagnosis; high titers more specific
Core Labs (All Patients).target: Negative (positive supports MMN but negative does not exclude)

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: IgA deficiency before IVIg (risk of anaphylaxis); IgM often elevated in MMN
May be mildly elevated in MMN (usually 1-3x ULN); markedly elevated suggests myopathy

Extended Labs.rationale: IgG subtype less specific but may be positive; helps differentiate from ALS if present
Other ganglioside antibodies found in some MMN patients
Monoclonal gammopathy associated with neuropathy; IgM paraprotein may be seen in MMN
Extended Labs.target: No monoclonal protein (IgM paraprotein sometimes present)

Extended Labs.rationale: Required before IVIg therapy; cryoglobulinemia evaluation

Rare/Specialized.item: CSF analysis (protein, cell count, oligoclonal bands)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: CSF protein typically normal in MMN (unlike CIDP where elevated); helps differentiate
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal protein (<45 mg/dL); normal cell count; no OCBs

Rare/Specialized.item: Genetic testing for hereditary motor neuropathies
Rare/Specialized.rationale: dHMN, SMA mimics if atypical presentation or family history
ALS-related genes if conduction block absent and ALS remains in differential

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: MMN typically has NORMAL protein (unlike CIDP)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (15-45 mg/dL); elevated protein favors CIDP

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Exclude MS or inflammatory CNS process

Essential Studies.item: NCS/EMG with motor conduction block studies (CPT 95907-95913, 95860-95870)
Essential Studies.timing: Priority study; must include proximal stimulation sites to detect conduction block; test multiple nerves bilaterally
Essential Studies.target: Definite motor conduction block (≥50% CMAP amplitude/area reduction) in ≥2 nerves at non-entrapment sites; no sensory abnormalities

Essential Studies.timing: Exclude structural lesion if cervical radiculopathy in differential; root enhancement rarely seen in MMN
Essential Studies.target: Normal; no cord compression or root enhancement

Extended Studies.timing: Nerve enlargement or T2 hyperintensity in affected nerves; supports immune-mediated neuropathy
Extended Studies.target: Normal; increased T2 signal or enlargement in affected nerves supports MMN

Extended Studies.timing: Nerve enlargement at sites of conduction block; non-invasive alternative to MRI
Extended Studies.target: Normal nerve caliber; enlargement at conduction block sites supports MMN

Extended Studies.timing: Baseline respiratory assessment; respiratory failure rare but reported in advanced MMN
Extended Studies.target: Normal FVC (>80% predicted); NIF more negative than -60 cmH2O

Rare/Specialized.timing: Rarely needed; only if diagnosis uncertain after NCS/EMG and serologic workup; may show demyelination/remyelination at conduction block sites
Rare/Specialized.target: No vasculitis; onion bulb formation or demyelination/remyelination at block sites

Rare/Specialized.timing: Only if upper motor neuron signs present to exclude structural CNS pathology

Acute/First-Line.indication: First-line and ONLY proven effective therapy for MMN; initiates treatment

dosing.instructions: 2 g/kg divided over 2-5 days (e.g., 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days); infuse slowly; premedicate with acetaminophen and diphenhydramine if history of reactions

Acute/First-Line.contraindications: IgA deficiency with anti-IgA antibodies; recent thromboembolic event (within 3 months); uncompensated HF; severe renal insufficiency
Acute/First-Line.monitoring: Renal function (Cr before and 48h after); headache; BP; HR; infusion reactions; CBC

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (mild pain may occur in some MMN patients despite "pure motor" designation)

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day
Start 75 mg BID; increase to 150 mg BID after 1 week; max 600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain; SNRI alternative for patients with comorbid depression or anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily; increase to 60 mg daily after 1-2 weeks; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; MAOI use (within 14 days); uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma; CrCl <30
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BP; nausea; serotonin syndrome if combined with other serotonergic agents; LFTs

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain; insomnia associated with chronic neuropathy

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg q1-2 weeks; max 150 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Cardiac arrhythmia; recent MI; urinary retention; angle-closure glaucoma; concurrent MAOI
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day or cardiac risk; anticholinergic side effects; QTc monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Musculoskeletal pain from compensatory overuse; mild discomfort; IVIg premedication

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO q6-8h PRN; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Fatigue associated with chronic illness and IVIg therapy

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg qAM; may increase to 200 mg qAM; take early morning to avoid insomnia

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; history of left ventricular hypertrophy; mitral valve prolapse with stimulant use
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BP; HR; sleep quality; psychiatric symptoms

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Muscle cramps and fasciculations in affected limbs

dosing.instructions: Start 150 mg BID; may increase to 200 mg TID; max 900 mg/day; take with food

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Second- or third-degree AV block; hepatic failure
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG at baseline and dose changes; LFTs; GI tolerance

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Muscle cramps; adjunctive for cramp reduction

dosing.instructions: 400 mg PO daily to BID; may increase to 400 mg BID

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal insufficiency (use with caution; monitor Mg level); GI obstruction
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Serum magnesium if renal impairment; GI tolerance (loose stools)

Maintenance/Chronic.indication: Ongoing treatment; most patients require chronic maintenance IVIg; titrate to lowest effective dose and longest interval

dosing.instructions: Maintenance 1 g/kg every 2-4 weeks OR 2 g/kg every 4-8 weeks; titrate to minimum dose/frequency that maintains strength; many patients need lifelong therapy

Maintenance/Chronic.contraindications: IgA deficiency with anti-IgA antibodies; recent thromboembolic event; uncompensated HF; severe renal insufficiency
Maintenance/Chronic.monitoring: Renal function before each infusion; grip strength and clinical exam q3mo; headache; thrombotic events; hemolysis (DAT, LDH, haptoglobin)

Maintenance/Chronic.indication: Alternative to IVIg for maintenance; same total monthly dose; improved convenience; fewer systemic side effects

doseOptions.orderSentence: SCIg (Subcutaneous Immunoglobulin) — maintenance Weekly equivalent SQ

dosing.instructions: Convert monthly IVIg dose to weekly SQ (divide monthly dose by 4; increase total by 20% for bioavailability); self-administered at home; multiple infusion sites; max 50 mL/site
dosing.orderSentence: SCIg (Subcutaneous Immunoglobulin) — maintenance Weekly equivalent SQ

Maintenance/Chronic.contraindications: IgA deficiency with anti-IgA antibodies; thrombocytopenia; coagulation disorders
Maintenance/Chronic.monitoring: Local injection site reactions; serum IgG trough levels; clinical response q3mo

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.indication: Refractory MMN not responding to IVIg; last resort given toxicity; limited evidence

dosing.instructions: IV: 1 g/m² monthly x 6 months with MESNA; PO: 1-2 mg/kg daily; very limited evidence; reserve for severe refractory cases

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.pretreatment: CBC, LFTs, BUN/Cr, urinalysis at baseline; fertility counseling; pregnancy test
Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.monitoring: CBC q1-2wk; urinalysis for hematuria; BUN/Cr; LFTs; cumulative dose

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.indication: Refractory MMN; case reports/series suggest possible benefit in some patients; not well-established

dosing.instructions: 375 mg/m² IV weekly x 4 weeks; OR 1000 mg IV days 1 and 15; limited evidence in MMN

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.pretreatment: Hepatitis B/C screening; quantitative immunoglobulins; CD19/CD20 counts; vaccination update
Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.contraindications: Active hepatitis B; severe active infection
Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.monitoring: CD19/CD20 counts q3mo; immunoglobulins q3mo; infection surveillance

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.indication: IVIg-sparing agent; limited evidence; may allow reduction in IVIg dose

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; titrate to 1000 mg BID; trial of 6 months to assess IVIg-sparing effect

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.pretreatment: CBC, LFTs at baseline; pregnancy test; contraception counseling
Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.monitoring: CBC monthly; LFTs; GI symptoms; pregnancy prevention

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.indication: Investigational for MMN; complement-mediated mechanism targeted; limited data

dosing.instructions: Investigational use only; complement inhibitor; must vaccinate against meningococcus ≥2 weeks before starting

Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.pretreatment: Meningococcal vaccination ≥2 weeks prior; CBC; complement levels
Second-Line/Disease-Modifying (Refractor.monitoring: Meningococcal vaccination status; signs of meningitis; CBC; LDH

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist/neurologist for electrodiagnostic testing with conduction block studies, anti-GM1 antibody interpretation, and IVIg management
Infusion center referral for outpatient IVIg or SCIg administration and long-term maintenance therapy
Physical therapy for hand and upper extremity strengthening; grip strength optimization; adaptive strategies for weakness
Occupational therapy for hand function, adaptive equipment, and workplace modifications given predominant upper limb involvement
Pulmonology if respiratory symptoms develop (rare phrenic nerve involvement)
Social work / case management for insurance authorization of IVIg (costly therapy); disability documentation; home infusion coordination
Pain management referral if neuropathic pain is refractory to first-line agents

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED or call 911 if: sudden severe weakness, difficulty breathing, or inability to use hands for daily tasks — these may indicate acute deterioration requiring urgent IVIg
Report any new weakness in arms or legs, increased difficulty with grip, or worsening of existing weakness promptly, as this may indicate need for IVIg dose adjustment
IVIg infusions are lifelong in most patients; do not skip or delay scheduled infusions, as strength will decline without regular treatment
Report headache, fever, chest pain, leg swelling, or shortness of breath after IVIg infusion (may indicate aseptic meningitis, thrombotic event, or hemolysis)
Do NOT take corticosteroids (prednisone, methylprednisolone) unless specifically directed by your neurologist — steroids can worsen MMN
Maintain grip strength diary or functional assessments to help guide IVIg dosing adjustments at each visit
Inform all healthcare providers that you have MMN and that corticosteroids and plasma exchange are contraindicated for your condition

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular upper extremity and hand exercises to maintain and improve grip strength alongside IVIg therapy
Ergonomic workplace modifications to compensate for hand weakness: adaptive grip tools, voice-to-text software, modified keyboards
Adequate hydration before and during IVIg infusions to reduce risk of headache and renal complications
Annual influenza vaccination; pneumococcal vaccination; avoid live vaccines during immunosuppression if on cyclophosphamide or rituximab
Fall prevention measures: remove tripping hazards at home; use assistive devices if lower limb weakness develops; non-slip mats in bathroom

differential.features: CRITICAL mimic; upper AND lower motor neuron signs; fasciculations prominent; bulbar involvement; progressive; no conduction block on NCS; normal sensory exams
differential.tests: NCS (no conduction block in ALS); EMG (widespread denervation/reinnervation in non-myotomal distribution); anti-GM1 negative; upper motor neuron signs on exam

differential.features: Symmetric, proximal and distal weakness; SENSORY loss present; elevated CSF protein; diffuse demyelination on NCS without focal conduction block; responds to steroids AND PLEX
differential.tests: NCS (diffuse demyelinating pattern vs focal conduction block); sensory loss on exam; CSF protein elevated; response to steroids (CIDP yes, MMN NO)

differential.features: Multifocal demyelinating neuropathy but WITH sensory involvement; conduction block present; responds to IVIg AND steroids
differential.tests: NCS (conduction block with sensory abnormalities); clinical exam shows sensory loss; steroid-responsive

differential.features: Finger flexor and quadriceps weakness may mimic MMN; but weakness is proximal pattern; CK more elevated; muscle biopsy diagnostic
differential.tests: CK (more elevated in IBM); NCS (myopathic not neuropathic); EMG (myopathic units); muscle biopsy (rimmed vacuoles, inclusion bodies)

differential.features: Slowly progressive distal motor neuropathy; family history; no conduction block; onset typically younger
differential.tests: Genetic testing (HSPB1, HSPB8, GARS, DYNC1H1); NCS (axonal without conduction block); family history

differential.features: Progressive symmetric proximal weakness; lower motor neuron; no conduction block; genetic diagnosis
differential.tests: SMN1 gene deletion testing; NCS (no conduction block); EMG (chronic neurogenic pattern); symmetric weakness

differential.features: Asymmetric upper limb weakness; but follows root distribution; sensory loss in dermatomes; neck pain; imaging abnormalities
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (disc herniation, foraminal stenosis); NCS/EMG (root distribution not individual nerve territories)

differential.features: Unilateral distal upper limb wasting; young males; non-progressive after initial phase; no conduction block
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (forward displacement of posterior dura in flexion); NCS/EMG (limited to one limb); clinical stabilization

evidence.recommendation: IVIg is the only proven effective treatment for MMN (randomized controlled trials)
EFNS/PNS guideline on MMN diagnosis and treatment
evidence.source: [Joint Task Force EFNS/PNS. J Peripher Nerv Syst 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21199100/)

evidence.recommendation: Anti-GM1 IgM antibodies present in ~30-80% of MMN patients; supports diagnosis
Corticosteroids and plasma exchange are ineffective and may worsen MMN
evidence.source: [Joint Task Force EFNS/PNS. J Peripher Nerv Syst 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21199100/)

evidence.recommendation: SCIg non-inferior to IVIg for maintenance in MMN
evidence.source: [Harbo T et al. Eur J Neurol 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19469830/)

evidence.recommendation: Conduction block is the electrodiagnostic hallmark; must test proximal segments
Long-term IVIg prevents progressive axonal loss; early treatment improves outcomes
evidence.source: [Van den Berg-Vos RM et al. Brain 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12519564/)

evidence.recommendation: Cyclophosphamide has limited evidence for IVIg-refractory MMN

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; before and 2-4 weeks after IVIg dose changes
monitoring.action: Increase IVIg dose or frequency; shorten interval; evaluate for disease progression
Adjust IVIg; evaluate compliance; consider second-line if IVIg-refractory

monitoring.frequency: Before each IVIg infusion; 48h after infusion if risk factors
monitoring.action: Slow infusion rate; increase hydration; consider SCIg if recurrent renal issues
Evaluate for hemolytic anemia (IVIg-related); check DAT, LDH, haptoglobin if Hgb drops

monitoring.frequency: Q12 months or if clinical change
monitoring.action: Adjust treatment; re-evaluate diagnosis if NCS pattern changes

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; annually; more often if symptoms
monitoring.action: Pulmonology referral if declining; rare but possible phrenic involvement

disposition.criteria: Stable weakness without acute progression; no respiratory compromise; outpatient neurology follow-up arranged for diagnostic workup
New diagnosis with significant weakness requiring expedited workup; IVIg induction; concern for ALS requiring urgent differentiation; respiratory assessment
Respiratory failure (rare in MMN); aspiration risk; hemodynamic instability
All patients: q1-3 months during IVIg optimization; q3-6 months once stable; IVIg dose/interval titration
Established patients: regular IVIg infusions per schedule (typically q2-8 weeks); transition to SCIg at home if appropriate
